I know for a fact that I‚Äôve written other posts that just aren‚Äôt on here now, either because I wasn‚Äôt keen on them afterwards or they‚Äôve fallen by the wayside during countless moves from one platform to the other.

Several times over the years I‚Äôve tried to tell myself that I will post more on this blog, and sometimes it‚Äôs worked for a month or two, but for some reason I never stick to it. I think I‚Äôve been anxious that what I put out wouldn‚Äôt be good enough in some way.

entry.title: String interpolation with template literals
entry.content:
One useful feature in ES6 that I came across recently is template literals. Template literals can be used to store a sequence of characters in much the same way as string literals, but they come with some added bonuses.

Expression interpolation

To create a template literal we use back-ticks (` `) as opposed to the double or single quotes used for string literals. A basic example would be:

Both of these variables would evaluate to a string if they were logged out in console. The benefits of template literals become apparent when we take things to the next level and try to include variables within a string. Traditionally if we had a variable we could insert it into a string like this:

That is a very basic example but the closing of quotes and the inclusion of multiple + operators can become clumsy and unreadable when you‚Äôre dealing with large templates and multiple variables.

Template literals allow us to simply type the name of the variable into the middle of the string using the ${NAME} syntax.

We don‚Äôt need to worry about closing and re-opening quotes and there are no concatenation operators to worry about. Template literals give us a much cleaner method of interpolating variables into a string.

Multi-line strings

Another nice way we can make use of template literals is when we need to build multi-line strings in our JavaScript. For example if we need to output a block of HTML for a card template, we might normally write something like:

It‚Äôs easy to see how this could quickly get quite messy and it isn‚Äôt the nicest thing in the world to read. Template literals would let us write that code like this:

Much neater and much closer to natural HTML. We can get rid of the need to close and re-open quotes, we don‚Äôt need the + at the end of each line and we have even used the expression interpolation syntax from before to include our variables.

Template literals give us a much cleaner method of interpolating variables into a string and make handling multi-line strings much simpler.

entry.title: Angular scope in your console
entry.content:
Sometimes it can be really useful to inspect the data you‚Äôre working with on an Angular build. There are some plugins and extensions to help with this, like the Batarang extension for Chrome.

I prefer to have my scope in my dev tools console while I‚Äôm looking at a page. That way I can see how the data changes as I interact with the page, or view the data returned from an API. There‚Äôs a simple command which lets you do that.

Select an element in Chrome‚Äôs dev tools, paste that into the dev tools console and hit return. You‚Äôll get an interactive model of the scope for the selected element.

entry.title: Things that piss me off about the internet vol.1

link.title: Things that piss me off about the internet vol.1

entry.content:
There are a lot of things that piss me off about the web industry and the internet in general, so I thought I‚Äôd start a series of posts where I can rant about them.

Sketchnotes from conference talks

What the hell is the point in these? They are just scribblings that don‚Äôt capture anything about a talk, and are essentially a collection of disconnected sentences that barely relate to the subject.

How is that useful to anyone? It‚Äôs a collection of random words! You‚Äôre meant to take notes so you dont forget stuff and you can read it back later.

Sketchnotes are basically just a way for people to show everyone else how good they are at drawing. They just give people something else to post on Twitter, and have no use to anyone except the person who drew them.

Cat pictures

Don‚Äôt get me wrong I think cats are ace, I‚Äôve got a couple of my own. But who decided that every demo site or placeholder image should be a picture of a kitten?

Have a bit of imagination, there‚Äôs bloody cats everywhere!

Coffee

As soon as someone decides to embark on a career in the web industry, they also feel they need to become a bloody coffee connoisseur. Ordering in weird and random kinds of coffee from all over the world. It all stinks as much as each other so it makes no difference.

‚ÄúHave you tried these new beans from the arse-end of Ecuador? They are so aromatic and offer a much fuller flavour. I‚Äôm off to grind some beans right now actually. Don‚Äôt be silly, of course I will measure them out first! I could never go back to instant, oh god no.‚Äù

Random hipster

Piss off and fetch me a brew. And no I don't care what tea bags you use.

(I‚Äôve realised I‚Äôm a very easily annoyed person.)

entry.title: AngularJS - ngHide for oldIE
entry.content:
Yeah I know I know, old IEs are dumb and should be run over by a bus or thrown off a bridge and blah blah blah. But sometimes 20% of your client‚Äôs users are using IE7, and another 20% on top of that use IE8, so you‚Äôve got to deal with it.

The trouble is, to support these browsers you need to include a legacy version of Angular, but some pretty basic directives don‚Äôt work in these browsers,for example ngHide.

Hiding and showing elements based on whether a scope object is true or false is one of the most common things we do with Angular, so at work we built a custom directive which will work across all browsers.

I‚Äôve created a new module called ar.directives, and a new directive called arHide. You can call these what you want, ar is just my initials.

Isolated scope

I‚Äôve then got an isolated scope on the directive, and I‚Äôve created a property within it called arHide. The name of this property will correspond to the way I use the directive in my markup (ar-hide), therefore I can use the shorthand arHide: "=".

Our isolated scope property will always take the value of the ar-hide attribute whenever we use it in our app, and it‚Äôs clever enough to recognise the camel-case and look for its equivalent hyphenated attribute.

Adding functionality

The link option can be used when you want a directive to manipulate the DOM. In this case I‚Äôll be adding and removing the ng-hide class when an argument is true or false.

link accepts three arguments:

  • scope, which in this case is my isolated scope from earlier
  • element, which is the element this directive is called from
  • attrs, which is a reference to the attributes of the element passed in

I don‚Äôt need attrs in this case so I‚Äôve left it out.

I use $.watch to keep a constant eye on the argument provided in arHide, which translates to the ar-hide attribute in the markup. When this argument resolves to true I add the class ng-hide, if it‚Äôs false the class gets removed. Simple as that.

entry.title: Simple check for old IE
entry.content:
On a recent project I needed to be able to detect if a user was browsing using IE8 or 7, and serve different functionality to them if that was true.

After looking around a really easy way to do this is to simply check whether the browsers supports the leadingWhiteSpace feature, using jQuery‚Äôs $.supports method.

Old versions of Internet Explorer don‚Äôt support this feature, and therefore oldIE will be false on these browsers. You could then apply a conditional class to your body tag to style something differently, or write a quick if statement to check the value of oldIE before executing some script for example.

entry.title: A couple of problems I‚Äôve found using Flexbox

link.title: A couple of problems I've found using Flexbox

entry.content:
Let me preface this post by saying that Flexbox is completely ace, and there are so many awesome use-cases for it. The particular one I‚Äôm going to talk about here is a grid layout for a product listing. Four columns, two rows, and just a simple image and price for each item. The site I‚Äôm working on is WIP but as an example let‚Äôs say it could be the grid of products in the pen below. (Will only work in Chrome and latest Opera).

Pretty simple. If you view the HTML you‚Äôll see it‚Äôs nothing more than a simple ul, with each list item containing an img and an h1.

The CSS has some basic reset styles and then gets into the two classes .products and .product.

The .products class is where most of the flexbox work is done here. First we change the display property to flex - there are five lines for this as there are browsers which need a vendor prefix, and also some browsers who still need the older flexbox syntax. See here for an overview of where flexbox is at right now.

The next declaration on .products is flex-flow: row wrap;. flex-flow is a shorthand property used to define both flex-direction and flex-wrap at the same time. So in this declaration we are telling the flex-items to display from left to right, and to wrap onto a new line when they run out of room.

Wrapping in Firefox and Safari

The first problem I came across is that Firefox and Safari currently don‚Äôt recognise or support the flex-wrap property, meaning that the items will just continue to flow outside of the parent container. You‚Äôd need to write a fallback for these browsers that don‚Äôt support wrapping.

View this post in Firefox to see what this looks like.

Alignment issues

The other problem is a bit of a tricky one. If you‚Äôre listing products in a grid, it‚Äôs highly likely that you‚Äôre pulling that data from a database of items. It‚Äôs therefore highly likely that you‚Äôll quite often have a list of items that doesn‚Äôt give you enough items to fill up each row.

I want my items to have space between them, and for the last one in each row to butt up to the right hand edge of the parent container. This is possible by applying the property justify-content with a value of space-between to the container. This will line up the first item in a row with the left edge of the container, and the last item in the row to the right edge of the container, with the remaining space distributed evenly between all the items in the row.

As you can see, the top row looks great, but the second row looks a bit pants. It is possible to make the products align in the way I want, by changing the justify-content value to flex-start. However this doesn‚Äôt then distribute remaining space on a row between the product items. In theory I could make each item 25% wide, and then add an inner wrapper to each one so I can apply padding and create the effect of space between the items, but it just feels like there should be a built in solution via CSS.

I‚Äôm probably being too picky here. This solution is perfectly fine and works in Chrome. Obviously it isn‚Äôt ready to be used in a production environment yet because of the lack of browser support. But I‚Äôd love to know if there is a way to align the items distributing the available space evenly, but also aligning items in a row to the left.

entry.title: Responsive breakpoints
entry.content:
I just read this quote in .Net magazine:

‚Ä¶rather than [device-specific] breakpoints, I‚Äôd decrease browser width until things looked broken or cramped, add a breakpoint and repeat‚Ä¶

Dan Tello

This is what I‚Äôve always done and is exactly the way we should approach making sure responsive layouts behave properly.

I never thought the idea of having pre-defined breakpoints for iPhone, iPad and desktop etc was particularly useful, and in fact it seems much more aligned with an adaptive layout. Even when responsive design was just a baby there were already hundreds of devices with different widths so setting a few different breakpoints has never made sense.

At the end of the day it‚Äôs in the name: breakpoint. Find out where your design breaks, then fix it.
